Problem:
Consider a complex function \\( z(t) = x(t) + iy(t) \\) that satisfies the differential equation \\( \\frac{dz}{dt} = Pz + Qi \\), where P and Q are constants. We analyze the behavior under a Fourier transform given by \\( F(z)(\\omega) = \\int_{-\\infty}^\\infty z(t)e^{-i\\omega t} dt \\).

Can we recover the original function \\( z(t) \\) at t = 0 precisely after observing its Fourier transform spectrum \\( F(z)(\\omega) \\) at t = T without knowing the exact time-evolution dictated by P and Q?
Explanation: Without knowing how P and Q influence the function over time, the original condition \\( z(0) \\) cannot be uniquely determined from \\( F(z)(\\omega) \\) at t = T. As changes in amplitude and phase due to P and Q affect the spectrum temporally, the inversion from frequency back to time domain lacks the necessary data on these influences.
